Was seen on the 30th day of July, between
Cohanzy and Bombay Hook, by Capt. Jesse
Mode, and party of pleasure on board the
sloop Ann Eliza of Wilmington, Sea Serpent,
at the distance of hafa mile. After nearing it
to the distance of three hundred yards, some
conectured its length to be about sixty feet, and
breadth between the eyes about six feet, but be-
ing in coiled situation could not with correct
ness be ascertaned: being well provided with
guns and ammunition, and courageous crew, 1t
was unanimously agreed that we should bear
down on it, and make formidable attack. The
deck being cleared, every man was at his post
and ready for battle,--commenceda Il tremendous
fire which was kept up for several minutes
When we ceased, it was discovered that we had
literally torn it to pieces, and were making
preparations to take it on board, when lo TO our
great astonishment and notification, it proved
to be an old bed, divested Of its contents and al
most torn to pieces, which gave it very fright
iul appearance.


ONE OF THE CREW.

will not apply to our climate, which has
DRYER atmosphere and more ardent sun
than any part of Great Britain. Thus Lou
don SAYS, scare should be taken to propor-
ton the number of hay-makers to that OF
the mowers, so that there may not be more
grass on hand at time than can be man
aged. This proportion is about twenty nay
makers, (of which number twelve may be
women) to four mowers; the latter are some.
times taken half day to assist the former.
In this country it is thought that cutting the
grass is about half the labour of making and
securing the hay crop; and women are rare
ly employed.


In moving without due degree OF skill,
the labour is very severe. If mars scythe
is not we'll hung on the snath or snead, ne
will do better to hang it on fence, and be-
take himself to some other employment
than attempt to cut grass with 1t. ne
Farmers Assistant says, "the sneads most
commonly used are bent in twisted shape;
but some use a snead which is nearly Ill
the shape of half circle, and the latter are
always preferred by those who have become
used to them. They take a wider swath
with the same extension of the arms; larg-
er cut and therefore may be slower; requires
less STOPPING; and from the position OF the



of the scyhte into the grass, being more
twisted round to the right, little more is re-
qusite than bringing the body to its natural
posture to carry the scythe through"


I.oudon says, "the waste Of grass on being
dried into hay, is supposed to be parts in
four by the time 1t is laid on the stack, 1t IL
then further reduced by heat and evapora-
tion, in about a month perhaps about one
twentieth more, or 600 lbs. OF grass are re-
duced to o5 lbs. of hay, and between that
and 80 it continues through the winter
From the middle Of March till September,
the operations of trussing and marketing ex-
pose it so much to the sun and wlna, as 70
render it considerably lighter probably 90;
that is hay which would weigh 90 the instant
it is separated from the stack, would waste to
so lin trussipg. exposure on the road, and
at market for about twenty-four hours,) by
the time it is usually delivered to the pur
chaser. During the following winter. the
waste will be little or nothing. 1t is nearly
obvious that the same hay will weigh on de-
livery so in summer, and 80 in winter From
this circumstance. and others which relate
to price, farmer may determine what sea-
son of the year is most advisable tor him to
sell his hay"

The gate at c, is allowed to be hoisted
high enough to admit Sufficient quantity"
of water for milling purposes and no higher,
for this would exceed the rights OF the mill.
Now ! would transfer to u, or else to the

and reduce the opening at {, as much as
would retain in the forcbay; supply for the

the forcbay and nearly level with the bot

Elimination OF pressure upon the piston from
the fluid, of nearly II or 400 lbs, besides
proportion Of the friction.

u A man who was accustomed to deal in the
marvellous, told country cousin OF his that
he had three great curiosities in his posses
sion: an OK that can travel 500 miles day, a
cock that told the lour of the night, and
dog that could read in a superior manner.
Saws the cousin, "these are extraordinary
things indeed must call upon you, and
beg a sight Of them" The liar returns
home and tells his wife what had happened,
saying he had got into scrapc, and did not
know how to extricate himself. oh never
mind, says she, can manage it, lhe next
day the countryman called, and inquiring at
ter his cousin, is told that he is gone OFT to
Pekin. And what time is he expected back!
In seven or eight days How can he re-.
turn so soona' He's gone Oft upon our OK
.Appropus of that continues, the guest, I'm
told that you have cock that marks the
hour A cock happened just then to crow.
yes, that's he; he only tells the hour OF
night, but reports when stranger comes.
Then, your dog, that reads books! might
beg to borrow a sight of him. why, to
speak the truth, as our circumstances are
but narrow, we have sent the dog out to keep
a SCHOOL,

Singular Banle.-A few days since, 2
farmer in the town of Jefferson. observed his
dung-hill cock engaged in mortal combat
with a striped snake of about 18 or 20 inch
es in length. the cock, to all appearance, hav-
ing the decided advantage over his more wi.
iy though less nervous adversary, dealing
his blows in quick succession. employing al
ternately his bill and spurs. But the cunning
serpent, we'll aware that victory must de-
clare against him by fair combat, brought

nit. attacked keel boat on her return from
Fort Smelling to Wheeling, and got posses
sion of her. She was subsequently recap
tured by the crew. Several lives we're lost
on both sides.

set two crooks, or earthen pots, each ten
or twelve inches high, and absut the same
in diameter, 10 the two most infested parts

flashing Machne.-The New Brunswick
Times calls the attention of the public to a
Washing Machine exhibiting in that city.
by Phillip P. Grain. If it deserves the re-
commentator there given, it is valuable
invention. The Editor says it is valuable
invention. The editor says it is simple in
it's construction, is worked with little labour,
and does the washing in the best manner,
and with less injury to the finest garments
ahan the ordinary mode. II is calculated
that woman can do more washing in two
hours than can be done in day by the com
mon process of washing.

a lady in Glasgow has pair of shoes OF

formed at Corby, England, lately, by one
of Mr.. Towards gamekeepers, young
man named Camuthers He threw up tit
teen oranges in succession with his lett

The Batavia Times states, that Mr.. Bruce,
sheriff OF Niagara county, was summoned to
Albany BY the Governor to answer certain
charges preferred against him tor his sup
posed agency in the abduction of Morgan
and that the charges not being suhstantiatcd,
have been withdrawn.


A riot is said TO have taken place near
Kingston. Upper Canada, probably connect"
ed with the elections going on there, IN
which the authorities were obliged to Call
out the military, and that before the unhap-
py affair was quelled, several ofthc rioters
were shot.

| The Nantucket Journal contains an extract of
letter from Ealipolis, Ohio, describing slngu-
lar accident in salt well. \ person had been
| lowered to the bottom of the well, depth of
50 feet, for the purpose Of making some repair.
when finding it dark, he called FOR light
candle was procured, and was lowered to the
depth of about 20 feet, when the air OF the well
took fire. The person at the bottom was mme-
datcly drawn up---hs hands and face much
scorchcd, and his hair and whiskcrs consumed,
but he is likely to survive the accident.

A York paper gives the following
description OF the possessions Of the hon. ote-
phen Van Rensselaer,:


General Van Rensselaer, is the owner OF
a manor extending twenty-four miles square
on each side of the Hudson river, and OF
which Albany, the capital of the most I'M
portant State in the Union, is in the centre.
This manor embraces some of the finest
streams in the country, having sufficient fall
of water to afford almost innumerable mill
scites, and presenting advantages to manu-"
facturers that can hardly be surpassed"
Two men at Syracuse, New YORK, who
had sought shelter under hay stack, on the
2Oth ult. during shower, were struck by
lightning and killed. The electric fluid was
perhaps attracted by their scythes, which
they had imprudently placed near them,


In the vicinity of London upwards OF two
thousand acres of land have been dug to the
depth of from to 10 feet for brck-earth.--
The bricks from an acre Of brick earth pro-
duce about Is, 900 dollars; and the sum paid
to the owners of the soil is $1,000 per acre.
An acre at four feet deep, yields four
millions Of bricks. In the manufacture of
bricks, the earth is mixed with coal ashes
and sand.

ming for which that reptile has been ccie-
brated from the beginning of the world to
the present time; and sezing his antagonist
by the thigh, in the rear, he completely Sc
cured himself from any further danger from
him. Thus situated the cock thought his
only safety was in fight" he accordingly
cIeaved the air msjcstically with his wings,
the snake keeping his fast hold, and dang
ling like tag lock, underneath. until the
cock. overcome with fatigue, alighted on a
neighboring apple tree. The snake imme~
dately coied his tail round the branch of a
tree-the cock again attempted flight, but
he could scarcely clear the limb, from which
he hung with his head downwards, making
every effort to escape, but all in vain, until
the farmer came to his assistance-kiled
the snake, and set him at liberty ty.--Schoha-

Cohanzy and Bombay Hook, by Capt. Jesse
Mode, and party of pleasure on board the
sloop Ann Eliza of Wilmington, Sea Serpent,
at the distance of hafa mile. After nearing it
to the distance of three hundred yards, some
conectured its length to be about sixty feet, and
breadth between the eyes about six feet, but be-
ing in coiled situation could not with correct
ness be ascertaned: being well provided with
guns and ammunition, and courageous crew, 1t
was unanimously agreed that we should bear
down on it, and make formidable attack. The
deck being cleared, every man was at his post
and ready for battle,--commenceda Il tremendous
fire which was kept up for several minutes
When we ceased, it was discovered that we had
literally torn it to pieces, and were making
preparations to take it on board, when lo TO our
great astonishment and notification, it proved
to be an old bed, divested Of its contents and al
most torn to pieces, which gave it very fright
iul appearance.


ONE OF THE CREW.

full articles.headline:
From the N. England Farmer.
HAYMAKING.
full articles.article:
Care should be taken to cut grass as close
and evenly as possible, because the bottom


is often interviewer with sort OF net work
of leaves and spires, which makes it much
more valuable than an equal length towards
the top of the growth. Besides, it is re-
marked that grass will not thrive we'll,
which is not mown close. 1t is very essen
tial to improve the fore part of the season,
for, says the Farmers Guide, sit has been
found by actual observations Tor number OF
years, that on an average more rain falls in
summer after the 18th and 90 tn of July than
before" The directions which are given in
English books on agriculture for haymaking

We sre happy to state that Mr.. Madison had
entirely recovered from his illness before he left
Charlottesville, and that he reached home in usu-
al health more than week ago. MI. Monroe,
who accompanied him, was well.


II is stated that Il great mercantile house in
the city of Mexico had failed, and was deficient
to the amount of eight hundred thousand dollars,
the creditors principally in Europe and the U.
States.

will not apply to our climate, which has
DRYER atmosphere and more ardent sun
than any part of Great Britain. Thus Lou
don SAYS, scare should be taken to propor-
ton the number of hay-makers to that OF
the mowers, so that there may not be more
grass on hand at time than can be man
aged. This proportion is about twenty nay
makers, (of which number twelve may be
women) to four mowers; the latter are some.
times taken half day to assist the former.
In this country it is thought that cutting the
grass is about half the labour of making and
securing the hay crop; and women are rare
ly employed.


In moving without due degree OF skill,
the labour is very severe. If mars scythe
is not we'll hung on the snath or snead, ne
will do better to hang it on fence, and be-
take himself to some other employment
than attempt to cut grass with 1t. ne
Farmers Assistant says, "the sneads most
commonly used are bent in twisted shape;
but some use a snead which is nearly Ill
the shape of half circle, and the latter are
always preferred by those who have become
used to them. They take a wider swath
with the same extension of the arms; larg-
er cut and therefore may be slower; requires
less STOPPING; and from the position OF the



of the scyhte into the grass, being more
twisted round to the right, little more is re-
qusite than bringing the body to its natural
posture to carry the scythe through"


I.oudon says, "the waste Of grass on being
dried into hay, is supposed to be parts in
four by the time 1t is laid on the stack, 1t IL
then further reduced by heat and evapora-
tion, in about a month perhaps about one
twentieth more, or 600 lbs. OF grass are re-
duced to o5 lbs. of hay, and between that
and 80 it continues through the winter
From the middle Of March till September,
the operations of trussing and marketing ex-
pose it so much to the sun and wlna, as 70
render it considerably lighter probably 90;
that is hay which would weigh 90 the instant
it is separated from the stack, would waste to
so lin trussipg. exposure on the road, and
at market for about twenty-four hours,) by
the time it is usually delivered to the pur
chaser. During the following winter. the
waste will be little or nothing. 1t is nearly
obvious that the same hay will weigh on de-
livery so in summer, and 80 in winter From
this circumstance. and others which relate
to price, farmer may determine what sea-
son of the year is most advisable tor him to
sell his hay"


Punning in High Life and Lou Life

"Orator Emmons," whilst delivering his
speech the other day, cried out, in lit OF
rhetorical nspiration-"Have we oCIsars
herca" Eyes" cried out Hays, the consta-
BILE of this city, ~ am Seizer, and this is
my Pompey." putting his hand upon the
shoulder of dusky looking mulatto, whom
he had pursued (cfiiciAly) from New York.
Col. Mic. when Hays told him the story, OBJ
served with his characteristic felicity Of re-
partee, "that was the hun coiacidehtal, or
hun ad cdhtandum." The spectators (all be-
longing. to "good soeiety'') laughed heartl-
ly at this eifusion Of patrican wit.-N. YORK

Suppose A, B, c. d, to represent verti-
cal section Of the following;


G, the gate at present in the lower end OF
the forebay, and over the wheel. ID, the
trunk from the race to the forebay.


The gate at c, is allowed to be hoisted
high enough to admit Sufficient quantity"
of water for milling purposes and no higher,
for this would exceed the rights OF the mill.
Now ! would transfer to u, or else to the
mouth Of the trunk, this same regulation,
and reduce the opening at {, as much as
would retain in the forcbay; supply for the
pump, which should be placed parallel to
the forcbay and nearly level with the bot
tom Of it; by this arrangement consdera-
Bile saving of pipe would be produced, and
Elimination OF pressure upon the piston from
the fluid, of nearly II or 400 lbs, besides
proportion Of the friction.


That the plan the Watering Committee
are now pursuing, will soon be Abandoned
and the one have offered, or some similar
one be ultimately adopted, it requires not
the spirit Of prophecy to forctcll with the
utmost certainty, but whether before the
useless expenditure Of large sums of money,
is not quite SO clear. =.
u A man who was accustomed to deal in the
marvellous, told country cousin OF his that
he had three great curiosities in his posses
sion: an OK that can travel 500 miles day, a
cock that told the lour of the night, and
dog that could read in a superior manner.
Saws the cousin, "these are extraordinary
things indeed must call upon you, and
beg a sight Of them" The liar returns
home and tells his wife what had happened,
saying he had got into scrapc, and did not
know how to extricate himself. oh never
mind, says she, can manage it, lhe next
day the countryman called, and inquiring at
ter his cousin, is told that he is gone OFT to
Pekin. And what time is he expected back!
In seven or eight days How can he re-.
turn so soona' He's gone Oft upon our OK
.Appropus of that continues, the guest, I'm
told that you have cock that marks the
hour A cock happened just then to crow.
yes, that's he; he only tells the hour OF
night, but reports when stranger comes.
Then, your dog, that reads books! might
beg to borrow a sight of him. why, to
speak the truth, as our circumstances are
but narrow, we have sent the dog out to keep
a SCHOOL,

century, the average quantity of wool i'm
ported into Great Britain, was seven million
two hundred thousand and six hundred
pounds.


Singular Banle.-A few days since, 2
farmer in the town of Jefferson. observed his
dung-hill cock engaged in mortal combat
with a striped snake of about 18 or 20 inch
es in length. the cock, to all appearance, hav-
ing the decided advantage over his more wi.
iy though less nervous adversary, dealing
his blows in quick succession. employing al
ternately his bill and spurs. But the cunning
serpent, we'll aware that victory must de-
clare against him by fair combat, brought
! into reauisitiop a portion Of the innate Gun.

nit. attacked keel boat on her return from

sion of her. She was subsequently recap

full articles.article:
set two crooks, or earthen pots, each ten
or twelve inches high, and absut the same
in diameter, 10 the two most infested parts
of the house, into which put few glls OF
molasses-against these leaned shingles,
making bridge from the floor to the rim,
that the roach might easily reach the lus-
cious bait below, whose fragrance filled the
chambers; and the better to allure them,
trailed some molasses along the road intend.
ed they should travel to their prisons, and
which they did travel in such numbers the
first night, that found the crooks halt I'LL
ed: the second night completed their de
struction.


flashing Machne.-The New Brunswick
Times calls the attention of the public to a
Washing Machine exhibiting in that city.
by Phillip P. Grain. If it deserves the re-
commentator there given, it is valuable
invention. The Editor says it is valuable
invention. The editor says it is simple in
it's construction, is worked with little labour,
and does the washing in the best manner,
and with less injury to the finest garments
ahan the ordinary mode. II is calculated
that woman can do more washing in two
hours than can be done in day by the com
mon process of washing.

a lady in Glasgow has pair of shoes OF
exquisite work manship; the uppersare made
of the skins Of rats, the leather is exceed
ingiv smonth and rs soft as the finest kid,
and appears stout and firm. 1t took six
skins to make the pair o. shoes, as the back
Of the skin is the only part stout enough for
use.


An extraordinary feat of shooting was per-
formed at Corby, England, lately, by one
of Mr.. Towards gamekeepers, young
man named Camuthers He threw up tit
teen oranges in succession with his lett
hand, holding his gun in his right. and hit
twelve out Of the fifteen with ball


The Batavia Times states, that Mr.. Bruce,
sheriff OF Niagara county, was summoned to
Albany BY the Governor to answer certain
charges preferred against him tor his sup
posed agency in the abduction of Morgan
and that the charges not being suhstantiatcd,
have been withdrawn.


A riot is said TO have taken place near
Kingston. Upper Canada, probably connect"
ed with the elections going on there, IN
which the authorities were obliged to Call
out the military, and that before the unhap-
py affair was quelled, several ofthc rioters
were shot.


The following toast was drank at late ccle-
bration in Upton, Mass :,

| The Nantucket Journal contains an extract of
letter from Ealipolis, Ohio, describing slngu-
lar accident in salt well. \ person had been
| lowered to the bottom of the well, depth of
50 feet, for the purpose Of making some repair.
when finding it dark, he called FOR light
candle was procured, and was lowered to the
depth of about 20 feet, when the air OF the well
took fire. The person at the bottom was mme-
datcly drawn up---hs hands and face much
scorchcd, and his hair and whiskcrs consumed,
but he is likely to survive the accident.


CJtu and Ccuutrv..-Of the number of
children annually born and nursed III Paris
nearly four IN seven die in one year; while
in one of the departments, (that OF Calva-
dos) this proportion does not exceed one in
eight.


A York paper gives the following
description OF the possessions Of the hon. ote-
phen Van Rensselaer,:


General Van Rensselaer, is the owner OF
a manor extending twenty-four miles square
on each side of the Hudson river, and OF
which Albany, the capital of the most I'M
portant State in the Union, is in the centre.
This manor embraces some of the finest
streams in the country, having sufficient fall
of water to afford almost innumerable mill
scites, and presenting advantages to manu-"
facturers that can hardly be surpassed"
Two men at Syracuse, New YORK, who
had sought shelter under hay stack, on the
2Oth ult. during shower, were struck by
lightning and killed. The electric fluid was
perhaps attracted by their scythes, which
they had imprudently placed near them,


In the vicinity of London upwards OF two
thousand acres of land have been dug to the
depth of from to 10 feet for brck-earth.--
The bricks from an acre Of brick earth pro-
duce about Is, 900 dollars; and the sum paid
to the owners of the soil is $1,000 per acre.
An acre at four feet deep, yields four
millions Of bricks. In the manufacture of
bricks, the earth is mixed with coal ashes
and sand.


A party of Winnebago Indians, on the 1st
} ult. attacked keel boat on her return from
Fort Smelling to Wheeling, and got possess
sion of her. She was subsequently recap
tured by the crew. Several lives were lost
on both sides.

Care should be taken to cut grass as close
and evenly as possible, because the bottom

ming for which that reptile has been ccie-
brated from the beginning of the world to
the present time; and sezing his antagonist
by the thigh, in the rear, he completely Sc
cured himself from any further danger from
him. Thus situated the cock thought his
only safety was in fight" he accordingly
cIeaved the air msjcstically with his wings,
the snake keeping his fast hold, and dang
ling like tag lock, underneath. until the
cock. overcome with fatigue, alighted on a
neighboring apple tree. The snake imme~
dately coied his tail round the branch of a
tree-the cock again attempted flight, but
he could scarcely clear the limb, from which
he hung with his head downwards, making
every effort to escape, but all in vain, until
the farmer came to his assistance-kiled
the snake, and set him at liberty ty.--Schoha-
